title: 107_s1502
content: The "COBRA Plus Act of 2001" is also known as the "Health Insurance Costs Credit" which amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide a refundable credit for health insurance costs. The "COBRA Plus Act of 2001" introduces a credit for health insurance costs paid by eligible individuals, limited to a maximum dollar amount based on monthly limitations. The "COBRA Plus Act of 2001" introduces a credit for health insurance costs paid by eligible individuals, limited to a maximum dollar amount based on monthly limitations. The credit amount is either 50% of the qualified health insurance paid for the month or a specific dollar amount depending on the type of coverage (self-only or family). The total coverage months for each qualifying event cannot exceed 9, and there is an inflation adjustment for dollar amounts after 2002. The section outlines the cost-of-living adjustment for the taxable year, with rounding rules for adjusted amounts. It defines a coverage month as a month where an individual is covered by qualified health insurance. The section defines a coverage month as a month where an individual is covered by qualified health insurance and specifies exclusions for months when the individual is eligible for certain health programs. The section of title 38, United States Code, outlines coverage months for individuals under specific health programs, excluding months when the individual is imprisoned. The term 'eligible individual' refers to a covered employee eligible for continuation coverage under qualified health insurance due to a qualifying event. Qualified health insurance includes COBRA continuation provision or coverage under section 8905a of title 5, United States Code. A qualifying event is defined as an event in section 4980B(f)(3)(B). Special rules apply for coordination with the medical expense deduction. The taxpayer's amount for medical expenses under section 213 is reduced by the credit allowed under this section. Rules similar to section 32(g) apply for any credit under this section. Payments for insurance must be substantiated, and regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary. This section does not apply to payments made after December 31, 2003. Information Reporting - Subpart B of part III of subchapter A of chapter 61 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section after 6050S. "SEC. 6050T. RETURNS RELATING TO PAYMENTS FOR QUALIFIED HEALTH INSURANCE." Any person receiving payments for health insurance coverage must file a return with the IRS, including the names, addresses, and TINs of the individuals covered. The IRS requires individuals receiving payments for health insurance coverage to provide information such as the amount of payments, coverage period, qualified health insurance credit advance amount, and other prescribed details. Creditable health insurance refers to qualified health insurance. Statements must be furnished to individuals as required by the IRS. Every person making a return must provide a written statement to individuals showing the name, address, and phone number of the person making the return, the total payments received, payment details, and the qualified health insurance credit advance amount received. The written statement required for tax returns must be provided by January 31 of the following year. Only the person initially receiving an amount on behalf of another is responsible for making the return. Assessable penalties may apply for non-compliance. Section 6050T of the tax code requires returns for payments related to qualified health insurance. Amendments to section 6724(d) include adding section 6050T(d) for insurance payments. A clerical amendment updates the table of sections. Sec. 6050T requires returns for payments related to qualified health insurance. A new criminal penalty for fraud is added under SEC. 7276 for offenses relating to health insurance tax credit. Any person misusing Department of the Treasury names for false association with insurance products or group health coverage in connection with the health insurance tax credit may face a fine of up to $10,000 or imprisonment for up to 1 year. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code and title 31 of the United States Code. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code and title 31 of the United States Code, including changes to the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code and title 31 of the United States Code include changes to health insurance costs, overpayments of tax, and penalties for offenses related to health insurance tax credit. Effective dates for these amendments vary, with penalties taking effect upon the enactment of the Act. Additionally, there is a provision for the advance payment of credit to issuers of qualified health insurance. SEC. 3. ADVANCE PAYMENT OF HEALTH INSURANCE CREDIT FOR PURCHASERS OF QUALIFIED HEALTH INSURANCE. This section amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow for the advance payment of the health insurance credit for purchasers of qualified health insurance. The Secretary will make payments to the plan sponsor or insurance issuer of a group health plan for eligible individuals who purchase qualified health insurance and have a qualified health insurance credit eligibility certificate. The term 'qualified health insurance issuer' refers to a specific type of health insurance issuer. For a group health plan, a qualified health insurance credit eligibility certificate is a statement provided by an individual to the plan sponsor or insurance issuer. It certifies the individual's eligibility for a tax credit, estimates the credit amount for the year, and includes other required information as determined by the Secretary. The qualified health insurance credit advance amount is an estimate of the tax credit allowable to an individual for the year, based on the insurance provided by the plan sponsor or issuer. No payment can be made without the required documentation provided to the Secretary. The health insurance issuer must provide the Secretary with the qualified health insurance credit eligibility certificate and the individual's return under section 6050T. The Secretary will prescribe necessary regulations for this section. SEC. 7527 allows for advance payment of health insurance credit for purchasers of qualified health insurance, effective January 1, 2002. A study is required by the Comptroller General of the United States by January 1, 2003, to assess the effectiveness of the amendments in increasing enrollment in group health plans under COBRA continuation coverage. The report will be submitted to the Committee on Ways and Means of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Finance of the Senate.
